thread.title: Massillon Jackson survives push from No. 17 Ellet, 77-68
thread.title_full: Massillon Jackson survives push from No. 17 Ellet, 77-68

author: Matt Goul, cleveland.com
title: Massillon Jackson survives push from No. 17 Ellet, 77-68
text:
Complete Box Score » 
AKRON, Ohio – Two top seeds in their respective boys basketball district tournaments, Ellet and Massillon Jackson showed each other Friday night why they received such billing. 
The final statement came from Jackson and its two Division I college-bound senior forwards, who let out a series of emphatic dunks in the final minutes of the Polar Bears’ 77-68 victory. 
Kyle Young and Logan Hill each tried to pull down the rim at Ellet as they scored the final six points on slams to pull away. 
“Just getting the crowd, that’s always the best — especially in a tight game when you can pull ahead with something like that,” said Hill, who finished with the final two slams. “It’s great.” 
A 6-foot-5 senior center headed to Toledo, Hill finished with 18 points and nine rebounds. Young scored a game-high 27 points, including two 3-pointers, and seven boards. 
A 6-7 senior forward bound to Butler, Young began the late dunk-off challenge with his team clinging to a five-point lead. 
“We got a little excited there being able to pull away there at the end,” Young said. 
This victory for Jackson (20-2), the No. 4-ranked team in last week’s final Associated Press state poll , was far from a sure thing. Even when the Bears jumped out to a 17-7 lead, Ellet (18-4) quickly climbed back. 
Charged with 6-9 senior A.J. Gareri , focused outside shooters and home-court advantage, the No. 17-ranked team in the cleveland.com Top 25 led for spurts throughout the second, third and fourth quarters. 
Gareri scored 21 points and grabbed nine rebounds. 
“We commended our guys, but we weren’t happy,” Ellet coach Mark Fisher said. “Some transition points there in the end, and we’ve got to stop transition points all of the time. That’s what we talked about after the game.” 
A couple of misses hurt the Orangemen offensively in the final minutes. They led 64-63 before Jackson guard Kyle Nicolas ’ 3-pointer gave his team the lead for good. 
“But you know what?” Fisher said. “We brought it tonight.” 
Nicolas hit four 3s and scored 16 points to fuel Jackson’s road win. 
Ellet hit eight 3s, including a trio of long shots from Jake Kline off the bench. Senior guard Jaret Jones added two more 3s and 14 points to keep Ellet in contention. 
The Orangemen are the No. 1 seed for the Division I Alliance District tournament, which they begin Saturday, March 4 with a sectional game against No. 6 Youngstown East or No. 8 Akron East. 
Jackson, meanwhile, will be the favorite in a loaded district at Canton. The Bears play a sectional first-round home game Wednesday against 11th-seeded Massillon Perry. 
“To go 20-2 with this group, man it’s been a great year,” Jackson coach Tim Debevec said. “And now our goal is to get to Columbus.”
